 Jacobus Van Bossuyt. sacrae theologiae doctor Lovaniensis
 96 februarii 1712, theologiam apud suos Lovanii docuit ab
 anno 17οΞ ad 1705. En vitae ejus compendium, quad nuper
 edidimus in Biographie nationale, ll. ool. 761-762.

 α Jacques-Ignace Van Bossuyt naquil te 1 novembre loco.
 a Elena, village des environs d’Alost. Son pare, qui pol-tail:
 ie nom de Gaspar. emit bailli d‘Eleneet grand nom-rioior
 des pauvres. Envoyé de bonne heure au college des peres
 Augustius a Enghien pour faira son cours d'humanités, lo
 jaune Van Bossuyt s’y distingue eonstumment parmi sea con-
 disciples. Apres avoir achevé ses eludes, ii entra, en 1690,
 dans -l’ordre de Saint-Augustin, tlt son novieiat sous la
 direction habile du pere Monard Van Roy; il vim ensuite ὸ
 Louvain pour étudier la theologie, et y soutint, uu mois de
 juin 1695. des theses publiques sous la présidence de son
 professeur Francois Pauwens. Vers l’année 1696, ses supe-
 rieurs lui conﬂerent la direction du college d’Enghien. foue-
 tions qu'il remplit pendant environ six ans. En 1702, il
 retourna a Louvain, prit le grade de licencié en theologie.
 et euseigna ensuite cette science, d'abord pendant trois ans
 aux jeunes religieux de son ordre a Louvain, plus lard,
 pendant huit ans, aux Bénédiclins de l’abbye d’Eenama.
 pres d'Audenardc.Enlretemps il se présenta a Louvain pour
 étre revétu des insignes du doctoral. ll fut. promu a cette
 haute distinction le ‘26 février 1719, avec Vincent van Seve-
 ren, religieux de l'ordre de Saint-Dominique. Deux ans plus
 tard. il fut nommé regent ου professeur de la l‘acullé de
 theologie, en remplacement du pere Le Drou, appelé a
 l'évéclié de Porphyre in partibus infidelium. ’

 « Grace a un extérieur noble et imposant. ä des manieres
 douces et agréables. le pere Van Bossuyt s⁷etait concilié
 l’affection et l‘eslime de tous. Aussi i‘ul-il élu, a l’unauimilé,
 provincial de l’ordre de Saint-Augustin en Belgique, une pre-
 miere fois le 12 mai 1715, et de nouveau le 7 mai 1724. Ii
 fut aussi nomme visitem· et déﬂniteur de sa province, et pre-
 fet de la mission hollandaise. Dans ces diﬂ‘érenles fonctions⁷
 il s'ailacha principalement a maintenir partout la discipline

 -308-

 monastique. et a combattre les tendances jansénistes. Il fut
 également un des plus zélés et des plus ardents promoteurs
 de l'Université de Louvain, et ne manqua pas d’user, en
 faveur de cette institution, du credit dont il jouissait a Rome
 aupres de quelques cardinaux,et ailleurs aupres d'autres per-
 sonnages inﬂuents. Mine par une longue maladie, il mourut
 subitement a Enghien,le 22 decembre 1727.dans la cinquante-
 neuviéme année de son age, et fut enterré dans I'église de
 son monastero, a proximité du maltro-autel.

 »Van Bossuyt nous a laissé un abrégé de theologie morale.
 Lorsqu‘il était professeur de son ordre, il en publia la pre-
 miere édition en 1709, sous le titre de : Theologia moralis
 contracta et dilucide, ad petitiones responsionibus adjunctis, ad
 instructionem singulorum proposita; 2 vol. in-12 de 334 et
 386 pages. Cet ouvrage. réimprimé plusieurs fois avec de
 legeres modiﬁcations et des additions peu considerabitis
 (entre autres ä Gand. en 1734 et 1741, et a Louvain en 1766),
 servit pendant iongtemps de manuel de theologie chez les
 Augustius de Louvain et dans quelques séminaires de Bel-
 gique. La doctrine morale de l’Abrégé est empruntée le plus
 souvent aux Aphorismes pratiques de Steyaert. Dans les
 questions dogmatiques, qui y sont parfois traitées, bien que
 le titre semble annoncer le contraire, l‘auteur se montre
 un ardent adversaire des sectateurs de Jansenius et de
 Quesnel. »

 Ce college, établi peu d'années apres la fondation de

 du pere Godefroid de Loe, religieux savant et zélé de

 lO février 1461; et, des ce moment, il jouit des memes

 1447.

 Les Carmes dont il est question ici sont des Carmes
 chausses de l’ancien institut (l), ainsi nommes pour

 vain, connus sous les noms de Placet et Tacet.

 jusqu’au mois de février de l’année suivante. 13 pluie ne

 n’avait vu pareille détresse. Ce ﬂéau engendra un peste ter-
 rible. La mortalité était si grande que les villes furent
 obligées d'improviser des cimetiéres dans des plaines et hors
 des lieux habités; on vit enterrer jusqu'ä 60 ou 80 cadavres
 dans une méme fosse.

 La population de Louvain en fut terriblement éprouvée.

 de trente personnes a l’hbpital. et Gramaye ajoute qu'il resta
 ä peine un tiers de nos habitants. Les cimetiéres des églises

 « Johannes Beets, doctor conspicuus, multa prestans vir-
 tute, in acutissimis disputationum certaminibus clarus, ad

 verba videbantur, et adeo gratiosus, ut ex concionantis ore
 pendentes cunctos aspexisses, salutis eterne poculum quem
 mulieris [lege multis] propinavit, memoriamque sui posteria
 {lege posteris] in benedictione reliquit. Nam multifariam
 doctrine ubertate profluens, inter alia complura eruditionis
 plena preceptorum [lege preceptorium] divine legis quam
 commendatissimum edidit, dicendi quodam leni, familiari et
 juxta subjectam materiam eloquenti stilo trudens in eo ad
 predicandum tam vehementer accommoda, ut in admonendis
 populis nihil oportunius, nihil vehementius, nihil denique
 utilius possit afferri. Nec puto facili [lege facile] alium quem·
 piam inveniri, qui eum non laude modo dignum, sed etiam
 admirandum in decalogi explanatione judicetur excellere. Et
 quia suppremi (t) non debet utilitas ingens et magna, ut ex
 opere tam frugifero, erudito sane et castigato, fructus

 omnis percipiat, ex archetipo impressione communicatum
 passim est.

 Le couvent des Carmes chausses fut supprime le 5 no-
 vembre 1796, a la suite de l”occupati0n de la Belgique par
 les révolutionnaires francais. Les bätimenls claustraux,
 ainsi que l‘église dédiée a sainte Catherine, furem vendus
 publiquement peu de temps aures. et démolis presque entie-
 rement en 1799. Les quelques restes échappés a la destruc-
 tion furent convertis en habitations privées. Le mur d’en—
 ceinte seul fut conserve; il existait encore il y a environ
 trente ans. ·

 Depnis le mois de janvier 1795 jusqu'au moment de sa
 demolition, l‘église des Carmes chausses servit de siege a la
 paroisse de Saint-Michel, dont l’église avait été convertie en
 Temple de la raison.

 54. COLLEGE DE domum DE PREMONTRE.

 Le college de Premontre, fonde ä Louvain en 1571
 et situe ὲ, l¹angleforme par les rues de Namur et des
 Chats (aujourd'hui rue de Her-iot). etait principalement
 destiné aux Norbertins des abbayes brabangonnes,»
 tandis que le college de Floreﬁ'e, dont nous ferons con-
 naitre l'histoire cai-apres, ne recevait que des religieux
 de cette derniére abbaye. «c En 1755, dit M. Van
 Even, le college fut reconstruit d’une muniere splen*
 dide. Il forme un carre long, qui presente une ma-
 gniﬁque facade entiérement en pierres de taille, a deux
 étages de fenétres rectangulaires, et _separäe de la
 rue par une avant-cour, fermee d’un mur. s» Louvain
 monumental, p. 302. '

 Voyez aussi, au sujet de l'histoire du college des
 Prémontrés a Louvain, HUGO, Sacri et canonici ordia*
 nis Proemonstratensis annales, II. coll. 529-532.

 par Paquot et Bax.

 (qui anno 1596 monasterium suum huic collegio inscripsit,

 Note compldmentaire pour l’histoire du college de l’ordre
 de Prémontré.

 A la suppression de l’Université en 1797, le prytanee de
 Saint-Cyr n‘aliéna pas le college de Prémontré. Le tribunal
 de premiere instance y fut installe le 321001 1800; mais il
 ,abandonna ce local au mois de novembre 1802. Le college
 servit ensuite d¹hopital militaire, notamment en 1810. Apres
 l’établissemem, a Louvain, d’une Universite gouvernementale
 par l'arrété de Guillaume I, roi des Pays-Has, en date du
 25 septembre 1816, on y installa l’auditoire et le cabinet de
 physique. ll conserve encore aujourd’hui cette méme disti-
 nation, mais renferme, en outre, les collections minéralo-
 giques de l¹Universite catholique.

 At the end of the « Vieux marche n» there is a large building
 yet occupied as a school, and now held by the Josephites;
 it was in it that Mr. O'Connell received part of his educa-
 tion.... Proceeding a little further you descend the « Place
 Saint-Antoine n and at the bottom of the hill, where the
 market ends, you may perceive a small porch or entrance
 not sufﬁciently large to admit a carriage. yet larger than an
 ordinary doorway. It is the entrance to what yet remains of
 the most celebrated of the Irish colleges of Louvain, dedi-
 cated to St. Anthony of Padua, and originally founded for
 Irish Friars Minor, of the order of St. Francis of the strict
 observance.

 The little porch that we have described is surrounded by
 a narrow band of cut stone. The following inscription is
 engraved upon the keystone of the arch: D. Ο. M. | COLLEGIUI

 | S. Aaron“ Puma: | ,ωηο 1753. This date merely records
 the erection of the entrance; for the college was founded
 more than two centuries before.

 The outer door opens at a touch, and you enter a little
 garden about ten yards in length; a narrow walk leads to
 another gate about the same dimensions, and upon either

 -407 -—

 side is a row of cedar and acassia. We rang the bell, and a
 « Frére de charité » (one of the present inmates), dressed in
 in black serge, the habit of his order, partially opened the
 door. Astonished, perhaps, at our intrusion, he was about
 closing it impatiently; however. the moment he heard that
 we were strangers, a new thought seemed to cross his mind,
 and the door opened to its greatest width. With downcast
 head he silently led us into the small waiting-room, and then
 bowing most profoundly, quickly departed. ·

 In the little entrance hall, close by the door upon the
 western side, a small stone of greyish marble is inserted in
 the white-washed wall; upon it are inscribed the following
 lines; they are in commemoration of laying the foundation

 The apartment of the superior, with the entrance hall,
 forms the western wing of the convent. The entire building
 is composed of three of these wings, forming the sides of a
 rectangle, with a court-yard in the centre, enclosed by a

 -410-

 wall at the eastern side. The northern and southern wings
 are more extensive than the western: a small corridor
 extends all round the court-yard forming a convenient pas-
 sage in wet weather; this is also laid down in small marble
 tiles. In the corridor adjoining the apartment of the supe-
 rior, there are a few portraits of Fransciscan Friars. and
 a large picture of St. Anthony conversing with some of the
 same order; upon the lower corner of this picture the follow-
 ing lines are painted : F. Bon" de Burgo guard" ﬁcri fecit in
 honorem sui patroni anno 1693 (1). The «ι Frere de charite n
 lately purchased this relique for about Liv. 8, and thus once
 more it is restored to its original destination; it would be
 well indeed if they were enabled to gather more objects of
 a like interest; but still better if the convent were restored
 to its original owners, namely Irish Friars of the order or
 St. Francis.

 As we were engaged viewing these pictures, we heard
 rather an animated discussion in the court-yard outside.
 For some minutes we were inattentive; however, the noise
 having rather increased. we began to think, how came such
 converse within these lonely wals? Upon looking out we
 saw two or three lads sitting upon stools busily employed in
 making shoes, others stood by and joined eagerly in con-
 versation; half a dozen of the brothers were also in the
 group. Supposing that it was some ordinary work that
 was being done, we turned away to our own occupation;
 the discussion became yet more animated, the words « Fran-
 caises. Belges » and c La liberté n struck our ear with loud
 and passionate emphasis. We looked out again, and the
 brothers called us over. There we found the professor
 general of the order in Belgium seated among them. The

 consists of several hundred scholars, although there are
 only eight of the brotherhood in the convent; and if the
 advancement and perfection in the other departments be
 at all equal to what we had seen, they may indeed be truly
 proud of their pious labours.

 The reader has now got every trace of his countrymen
 that can‘ be found in the college of St. Anthony; not another
 tine remains which can remind him that lrishmen once
 peopled these venerable walls. Perhaps, in our anxiety to
 describe these mementos and the interior of the building
 with something like accuracy, we have overlooked the
 external appearance. This is not very striking, the high wall
 that surrounds the little yard which separates it from the
 street breaks and interrupts the view; however it can be
 seen to better advantage from the court-yard in the middle
 of the building. or perhaps from the garden side; and in
 point of architecture it differs little from the generality of‘
 Flemish buildings; high walls of red brick, and almost
 upright red tiled roofs are their chief characteristics, and in
 these the college is not deﬁcient; they look very picturesque,
 when at all relieved by timber — the green foliage contras-
 ting with the colour of the brick, and the high gable pushing
 itself up among the lofty trees. The most pleasing spot about
 the college, whether in reference to the view, or otherwise,
 is the garden; and the superior having politely waited our
 convenience now invited us to enter.

 It contains about an acre and a half of land, and is taste--

 (1) On lit aetuellement sur la pierre “ammo-m unto. N'eunit-on pan
 fautivement v“ on mo lore do ln rest-untied do oeteo piano!

 -413—

 fully laid out in squares, full of the finest fruit and vegeta-
 bles; the red currents were particularly ﬁne, grown upon
 the standard trees; one square was entirely ﬁlled with the
 richest dahlias I ever saw grown in pots, and each pot
 plunged in a larger one full ofliquid manure. The river 0er
 surrounds the garden upon two sides. The old a boucherie n
 of the convent is now occupied as a garden house; from it
 the convent is seen to great advantage, with its lolly walls
 covered with luxuriant vines; at the eastern end, and sepa-
 rated from the garden, are the remains of lhe old printing
 house; it is the only part of the establishment not in pos-
 session of the present proprietors, and is now occupied as
 a ware-house.

 While sloping along the walks of this interesting spot,
 and thinking of the days when Conry and O’Clery. Ward and
 Hickey, were here busily employed, the brotherhood joined
 us in the garden; we seated ourselves under a chesnut tree;
 the superior was anxious to know whether the diﬁ‘erent
 religious orders in Ireland were any particular dress. and
 appeared astonished when told that even the secular priests
 did not do so. After having remained some time with the
 « Freres de charite, n we wished them good by, and departed
 perfectly satisﬁed with our visit. and under many obligations
 to them for the civility and kindness with which they treated
 a perfect stranger.

 Having now described all that remained of this college,
 the reader may be disposed to know something of its history.
 lregret, that there are no materials extant abroad, as tar
 as I can discover, which would enable one to put together
 anything like a consecutive narrative upon the subject. There
 are no records to be found at Louvain, in reference to the
 college of St. Anthony, nor in the Archives of Brussels, where
 we anxiously hoped that they should be found. However,
 the reader is not to suppose that materials are altogether
 wanting for this purpose; such is not the case. The different
 publications that emanated term the membres ot' the college
 during the 17th century, and the lives ol'thc authors them-

 -414-

 selves are subjects of great interest. From this it will be
 seen that no college in Europe produced more within the
 same period. than that of St. Anthony; and it” we remember
 that at the same time the Irish pastoral college of Louvain
 engrossed within its walls numbers of distinguished scho-
 lars. our countrymen, as did also the Irish college of the
 Dominicans; then, indeed, it will be seen, that it‘the labours
 of all be taken together, they certainly remain unequalled
 by any contemporaneous collegiate institutions that we
 know of, and remain a proud and lasting monument of the
 learning and zeal of the Irish nation.

 From the inscriptions we have before given, it may be
 seen that the college of St. Anthony was founded in the year
 I609; the necessary funds were supplied through the libe-
 rality of Philip the Third, king of Spain and the Indies. and
 by the exertions ofthe illustrious Florence Conry, subse-
 quently archbishop of Tuam. It does not appear where the
 brotherhood resided in the city ol'Louvain, until the year
 1617, when upon the 9th of may, prince Albert ol the Bel-
 gians and his princess Isabella Clara Eugenia, laid the foun-
 dation stone of the present edifice (I). The fame of Conry.
 both for piety and learning, was sure to make his college
 a point of attraction, for the most celebrated Irish scholars.
 of the order of the strict observants, and consequently
 many of them speedily gathered about him, and the schools
 acquired both fame and reputation. One oflhe most distin-
 guished of Father Conry’s assistants in this undertaking was
 Hugh Qaghwall (2), who was also raised from the guardian-

 ships and professor's chair of his college, to the dignity of
 archbishop and primate, having succeeded Peter Lombard in
 the see of Armagh. Bonaventure Hussey, a native of Ulster,
 and a man «in great esteem, for his singular skill in the
 language and history of Ireland n, was elected ﬁrst guardian
 or president of the college. It is to his labour perhaps, with
 the assistance of the Fathers Conry and Mac Caghwall, that
 we are indebted for the ﬁrst book printed in the Irish
 character.

 These distinguished men, though at a distance from their
 country, were present with her in sympathy and hope; they
 longed to cherish and to foster their language, one of the
 great elements ofa nation, and through its medium to speak
 words of comfort or instruction, from a foreign yet a friendly
 shore. In the year 1608, a small catechism in the Irish
 character and language, and written by Bonaventura Hussey,
 was printed at Louvain; a second edition ο1· the same work
 appeared in Antwerp 1611. α The mirror ol‘a christian life ».
 from the pen of Conry, appeared in 1616, and Mac Cagh-
 wall’s « Mirror of penitence » was published likewise at Lou-
 vain in 1628. In the year 1617, Anthony Hickey. a native of
 the county Clare, wasguardian of the college; upon the 17th
 of march, in the same year, Patrick Fleming joined the com-
 munity, and alter having spent some time at Louvain,
 proceeded to Rome, and upon his way thither was met at
 Paris by his countryman Hugh Ward (1). To this accidental
 meeting may be traced some very celebrated works upon
 Irish ecclesiastical and general history. We allude to the
 « Acta Sanctorum veteris et majoris Scotiae seu Hibernia; »
 by John Colgan, and the «Annals of Donegal » of Michael
 O‘Clery.

 Father Fleming, having pressed upon Hugh Ward the
 importance of collecting materialsul‘or the history of the
 Irish saints. proceeded upon his journey into Italy; every
 thing that could be collected in that country he transmitted

 to his friend, and afterwards, returning to Louvain, became
 a professor in the college. Ward having then dispatched one
 of the brotherhood, Michael O’CIery. into Ireland, with a

 proceeded to arrange all that came to hand. During ﬁfteen
 years Michael O‘Clery was diligently and unceasingly occu-
 pied in his labours. For a period of this time Florence Gray,

 afterwards appeared in the α Acta Sanctorum ». However,
 before the collections were completed, or before any portion
 of them was printed, Hugh Ward died in the year 1635.

 Upon the death of Ward this great work appears to be
 suspended for some time. However, another of the brother-
 hood. John Colgan, a native of Donegal, having found the
 materials to his hand, arranged and committed to the press
 these volumes of which we have spoken. The second is
 dedicated to Thomas Fleming, one of the confederate
 bishops, and who had been in early life guardian and pro-
 fessor of this college. We need scarcely remind the reader
 of the fame of this work; the editor was classed with Bollan-
 dus of the Jesuits. the most eminent divines praised it for
 learning and ability. and poets wrote in praise of the author :

 Qui cupit Hibernae regionis noscere gentem,

 In the year 1667 there were about sixty students in the
 college. Among them were two sons of counts, two vis-
 counts and four barons, with many others of distinguished
 families. Four missionaries, whose labours are proverbial,
 were sent from this college into Scotland : Cornelius Ward,
 Paul O’Neil, Patrick Hegerty and Patrick Brady. Edmond
 Cane, also ol* this college, suffered martyrdom.

 -417-

 While Michael O'Clery was employed as we have seen.
 many documents upon the general history of Ireland of
 course presented themselves, and induced him to under-
 take, with some little assistance from others of his order, the
 herculean task of collating and compiling a body of annals
 upon the general history of the country. These he carefully
 transcribed, and this is the manuscript generally called the
 a Annals of the Four Masters ι, and which is now in course
 of publication (1).

 Some time after the death of Colgan, which happened
 about the year 1658, Edmond Curry, a distinguished orator of
 this college, was thrown into prison, and at last suffered as
 a martyr. Thomas Geraldine and O'Cahan, men remarkable
 for their learning, piety and eloquence, suffered a like fate.

 From that year [1667], there exists nothing, that l could

 pilgrim, some Old Mortality will bend his steps towards
 Louvain. From the present occupants every facility may be
 expected, and, perhaps, it may not be to much to hope, that
 so desirable an object could be completed, and the inscrip-

 The low situation of the town and the proximity of the
 convent to the 0er rendered the overﬂowing of that river in
 the year 1784 a disastrous event to the Franciscans. All their
 cattle, wood and property of every kind was destroyed (2).
 In the midst of this deluge our coutrymen did not forget
 their heroism and charity. Two of the brotherhood seeing
 a boat vainly endeavouring to carry assistance to some
 unfortunate being, on the verge of destruction, were attrac—
 ted by their cries, and hastening to the spot. they plunged
 into the water,and were the means of rescuing the sufferers
 from a watery grave. But deeper and more trying calamity
 than any they yet suffered was soon approaching : the French
 possessed the town in 1796; the convent was dismantled, its
 little property was conﬁscated, their church was desecrated,
 and ﬁnally their premises were sold; subsequently it passed
 into the family Van Anderode, and the preSent occupants the
 «Fréres de charité i) purchased it from that gentleman in
 the year l832. We have now finished this notice of St. An-

 Ewtrait du Freeman's Journal du 24 janvier 1879.

 Bur a few months since, the Rev. James J. Ryan. B. D., of
 the archdiocese of Cashel, appealed to the Irish public
 through our columns for funds necessary to restore some
 interesting monuments of distinguished Irishmen and Irish-
 women resting beneath the cloisters of the old Irish Fran-
 ciscan convent of St. Anthony, Louvain. The sum asked for
 was only Liv. 20, which was promptly subscribed, and the
 subscriptions were duly acknowledged at the time in our
 paper. The patriotic priest of Cashel lost no time in getting
 the work accomplished. by engaging the services of the
 Rev. Dr. Reusens. professor of archaeology in Louvain, and
 in procuring correct copies of the effaced inscriptions,
 which have been faithfully restored on the tombs. These
 have been taken up from under foot in the common cloister
 passage and placed as mural adornments, safe from further
 eﬂ‘acement. The Rev. Mr. Ryan had the great pleasure of
 ﬁnding the whole projected work completed last october,
 and to the perfect satisfaction of all the Irish University
 residents and archaeologists of Louvain. The work, however,
 although based on the most moderate estimates, cost some-
 what more than had been at ﬁrst supposed, some marble
 inlaying and repairing the cloister ﬂoor being required; yet
 we are happy to announce that the sums collected by the
 Rev. Father Carey, Ο. S. F., and the Rev. Father O'Hanlon,
 C. C.. sufﬁced for the work, leaving a small balance in the
 Rev. Mr. Ryan's hands.This gentlemen is at present in Rome.
 but he purposes returning to Louvain, when he would be
 exceedingly anxious to procure means to achieve a still
 greater work for Ireland. The celebrated preservers of our
 country’s history in the seventeenth century, Father Hugh
 Ward, Father John Colgan, and Brother Michael O’Clery are
 buried in St. Anthony's convent, yet no monument marks
 their respective graves. The Brothers of charity have pro-
 mised a place in their chapel for a mural tablet to comme—
 morate them; and if Irishmen are willing to furnish the

 -420-

 small amount required, the Rev. Mr. Ryan. who returns to
 Belgium next summer, would most cheerfully complete a
 work, creditable alike to himself, to the illustrious dead, and
 to Irishmen all the world over. In any case, he means to
 erect a tablet. with an inscription commemorating the late
 restoration. We hope, however, he shall be encouraged to
 accomplish all he desires, and in a manner to delight his
 coutrymen at home and abroad.

 11 fut fondé, en l'année 1660, par les soins de l'abbé

 Note compldmentaire pour l'lu'stoire du college de Villen.

 Ia ﬂn du xvmc siecle. Les beaux baumenls, qui avaient ete si

 tions particuliéres. On respecta toutefois les construetione,
 qu'on se contenta de diviser en plusieurs maisons par des
 cloisons intérieures. Le corps principal des bätiments
 servit, pendant dc longues nuntios, de domeure et de maga—
 sins ä un négociant en vins. Les religienses Redemptoris-
 tines tirent. en 1873, l‘acquisition de l’ancien collége‘ de
 Villers, et y etabiirent une nouvelle communauté de iem·
 congregation par des colonies envoyées des convente de
 Bruges et de Malines. Ellos y séjournérent jusqu'en £889.

 bui-neme du college, et y installa ses taboratoires de mi-
 croscopie, de biologic celloiaire, de baclériologie et d’em-
 hryologie homine et comparée;

 58. Couvmwr ου COLLEGE DES ORAromnNs.

 Peu apres leur arrivee a Louvain, en 1626, les
 Oratoriens se ﬁxémnt dans les locaux assez spacieux
 ou la pedagogio du Faucon avait existe jusqu’en 1543,
 et qui, depuis cette époque, etaient occupes par les
 Bénédictius de Saint-Bertin de Saint-Onner (l). En
 1641, ils achetéreut, de l'abbayc de Vlierbeek. pour
 une somme de 34,000 ﬂorins, les bätiments de l'ancien'
 convent des Bogards, qui appartenaient ä cette abbaye
 depuis la suppression de ces religieux et leur incor-
 poration a l'abbaye benedictino. Ce convent emit sitne
 dans la rue de Malines, pres et en dehors dela pre-
 miere enceinte de la ville de Louvain. Les Oratoriens
 s'y transponerent immediatement et y construisirent
 une nouvelle eglise (2).

 Les Oratoriens furent supprimes le 4 fevrier 1797,
 et leur couvent vendu l'année suivante. L’église et
 quelques bätiments contigus furent demolis immedia-
 tement. Les constructions, qui longeaient la rue de
 Malines, ont ete conservees, et sont. occupees aujour-
 d’hui par l'établissemem connu sous le nom de Jardin
 des Oratoires.

 1. - Fondation du collage (1).

 Domus Oratorii Domini lecu. Anno 1564, sanctus Philippus
 Nerius Romae communis vitae formam incepit cum sociis
 paucis et selectis, videlicet Caesare Baronio, Alexandro
 Fideii, Joanne Francisco Bordino, Jacobo Salortio et Joanne
 Rausico. Quem coetum postmodum, a frequenti orationis
 communis exercitio in oratorio seu sacello sancti Hieronymi,
 Congregalionem Oratorii appellare placuit.

 Optabat quidem sanctus Philippus. utpote animarum ac
 disciplinae ecclesiasticae zelator eximius, ut ubique gentium
 forma vivendi apostolica instauraretur in clero. atque adeo
 ut collegia ecclesiasticorum sine votis in communi viventium
 fundaremur; verum numquam induci potuit, ut ea cum
 Oratorio Romano pateretur esse connexa seu unita, quam·
 quam haec unio ob specialissimas rationes domibus Neapo-
 litanae, Septempedanae et Anxanae fuerit indulta.

 Erecta sunt interim in pluribus ltaliae locis Oratoria dicta
 Neriana, ob similitudinem et maximam aliinitatem cum con-
 gregatione a beato Philippo Nerio instituta, prout et in Galliis w
 atque in ipso Belgio nostro, qualia sunt Oratorium Toniense
 in dioecesi Genevensi et ducatu Chablasii, Oratorium beatae
 Mariae Gratiarum dioeceseos Forojuliensis in Provincia,
 Aspricollense (de Montaigu) in Brabantia, Cerviense et Bra-
 niense in Hannonia. Duacense et Ostendanum in Flandria,
 tametsi pleraeque ex illis congregationibus postca transie-
 rint ad congregationem Oratorii Domini Jesu per cardinalem
 Berullum erectam.

 Uberrimos dictae congregationis fructus eum viderent
 nonnulli Galliae antistites aliique viri percelebres. anhelare

 (l) Voyez le Chronicon oonyreoationis Grater“ Domini Im, pp. l-9.

 ~493—

 coeperunt. ut et in Gallia consimilis sacerdotum sine votis
 viventium societas erigeretur, atque prae ceteris hoc opus
 ad optatura exitum perduxerunt sanctus Franciscus Salesius,
 eminentissimus cardinalis de Jojosa. sacri collegii princeps,
 et Petrus Berullus. postmodum et ipse galero cardinalitio
 insignitus. Sed. cum de futuro capite disceptabatur, impel-
 lente Salesio. omnium vota conspirant in Berullum; qui
 onus. superveniente expresso et absoluto episcopi sui man-
 dato, tandem admittit, atque 11 novembris 16M, Parisiis
 fundamenta posuit congregationis Oratorii Domini Jesu;
 quam deinde die 10 maii 16l3 approbavit atque conilrmavit
 summus pontifex Paulus V. ut patet ex bulla, in qua praelatus
 Berullus. ad preces serenissimae Galliarum reginae et Hen-
 rici, episcopi Parisiensis. totius congregationis praepositus
 generalis constituitur, et varia privilegia ipsi congregationi
 conferuntur; coepitque ex tunc vocari congregatio Berullana
 Oratorii Domini Jesu.

 Paulo post, seu pene ab initio institutae congregationis

 Gelasius Matlhaeus seu Mac-Mahon, primogenitus e nobili

 nuncupatis, in Hispaniam remissus, philosophiae theolo-
 giaeque operam dedit in Vallisoletano divi Pauli coenobio.
 (ubi Hiberni complures Dominicani ali solebant. Lovanium
 revocatus, hic lector, studii magister, regens secundarius, bis
 primarius, et bis prior fuit; tum ordinis praesentatus, ut illi
 vocant, deinde magister creatus est. Reversus in patriam,
 eo fructu laboravit, ut nonnullos etiam haeresis praecones
 ad Ecclesiae castra reduxerit. Prior ibi Garlingfordiensis,
 plaudente generali Dominicanorum praeposito, provincialis
 electus est; et quadriennium solitum emensus, eodem
 petente, dum ex Hibernia anno 1691 ab haereticis pulsus
 esset, ad biennium continuatus fuit. Quo tempore elapso,
 totius ordinis delinitor constituitur. Denique sacram theolo-
 giam in conventu Reviniensi ad Mosam aliquamdiu inter·
 pretatus, ibidem maligna febri correptus, mortalitatem exuit
 11 februarii 1703, aetatis anno 59°. Vir et elegantiorum
 literarum non imperitus, et in scholastica theologia non
 parum versatus, licet verborum admodum parcus.

 Le college des Croisiers, comme tous·les autres etablis-

 quamvis plurimum onere militari qravatum, satis sanum tectum

 maligm's temporibus solus in dicto colleyio fuit. et adhuc de
 praesenti est, et aliquo tempore adhuc Mimic videtur, donec
 plures alendi ea· proventibus colleqii am commoditas (1). La
 situation ne s'améliora gnere dans la suite. Au commen-
 cement du xvn= siecle, nous ne trouvons encore qu'un seul
 religieux dans Petablissement. Les appartements etaient
 occupes par des laios. L'état de delabrement dans lequel se
 trouvaient les batiments du college était tel que les religieux
 se virent dans la necessite de les vendre aux Freres Mineurs
 de l’0hservance (appelés aussi Récollets), aﬂn de pouvoir,
 au moyen du produit de la vente, placer, selon les intentions
 du fondateur, trois ou plusieurs religieux dans un autre
 college de l'Université. L’acle de vente fut approuve par le
 recteur de l'Université le 15 mars 1616 (2). Gene formalite
 était indispensable pour la validite du contrat; car, par suite

 A la suppression du college, les Groisiers furent places
 au college Liegeois, qui avait ete erige quelques aunees
 auparavant par le prince-eveque Ernest de Baviere en laveur
 des sujets les plus distingues de son diocese. Voici ce que
 nous lisons, au sujet de l‘admission des Groisiers au college

 et reliquam vitam et rerum agendarum vota continet. Audebo
 igitur, quid sentiam, breviter et privatim exponere. tuo
 subjicere judicio, quae expono. Nemo enim de lilio melius
 quam pater statuit : sed tu quid sit patrem esse, unus
 omnium optime intelligis. Quare non tam sententiam meam
 promam, quam tuam confirmabo : quae est compendium per
 tot ambages, per tot salebras quaerere; floridisque adhuc
 annis, ad studiorum maturitatem pervenire In puero vero
 partim animum, partim ingenium specto. Ille virtutibus, hoc
 artibus et elegantiis imbuendum. Virtutes fundamentum
 pietatem ac religionem habent. quae deinceps pro indole
 ac fortuna cujusque assumuntur. Aliis enim satis est libera·
 litatis pulchritudine amabiles esse; alios magnificentiae
 heroica quaedam majestas decet : quasi dicam, et in vir-
 tutibus vulgus esse, aliquas contra eminere. Omnes vero
 discet puer ingenuus et illustri loco natus, ut peculiares
 quasdem praecipue exerceat. Sine cibo nemo vivit, sine vir-
 tute nemo magnus est : sed regum tamen principumque
 mensae deliciis non plebeis instrui solent. Ornentur omnium
 animi, ut boni siut; bi grandiores etiam splendeant. Ab
 animo tamen ad ingenium quoque veniendum est. Ingenium.
 ut dixi, artibus et elegantiis colitura artibus, quas liberales

 hujus et aevi sunt) varietate constant. lu linguis aliae mutae,

 Apti videmur linguis. quia his plerumque conatum omnem

 inspicimus. Unde remedium? a bona institutione. Rerum
 instrumentum sermo est; bic parandus, priusquam res aggre-

 quae vernacula non est : Latinam esse, quam domi non
 didicimus. Usus sane, quae non est. vernaculam faciet. Nulla
 nobiscum nascitur; quaevis, ut sic dicam, adoptari potest.

 quam nutricem reliquissent. Tot scholarum ambages inter

 tota pueritia et adolescentia occupatur, et imperfecta adhuc
 latinitas est. Viri, exantlatis scholarum laboribus, balbutiunt;
 et qui scientias tractant rudi audent lingua contenti esse.

 pueri decennes ingenium animumque colerent : ante omnia
 linguam Latinam usu discerent : hinc artes; sed quibus
 nobilitas potissimum exornaretur. Usum tamen nolim prorsus
 nudum esse; verum subsidio brevissimorum praeceptorum

 disciplina generosi puerorum animi, et cum in plebeio scho-
 larum pulvere adolescunt, nil nisi scholam habent. Utinam
 minor grammaticae pompa easel! Utinam per linguam potius
 ad praecepta, quam per praecepta ad linguam via essetL Nunc
 una latinitate exhauritur indoles. et ad artes deinde tarda
 est. An dicam ? Evilescit quicquid tanto temporis dispendio
 constat. Quis deinde ad prudentiam, ad sapientiam, ad cogni-
 tionem sui venitt Quis artes inspicit pacis_ et belli? Quis
 veteres sibi Graecos autRomanos proponit,litterarum auxilio
 et fortes et felices? Nobilis puer, et reipublicae militiaeque
 victurus, nisi ethicis ac politicis instructus sit, nisi histo-
 riam ac mathesin calleat, frustra mihi Latinus erit; frustra,
 quae hodie post latinitatem tradi solent, hauriet. Linguam
 igitur discet, sed compendio; ut ad res artesque transferatur.
 Hoc compendium usu definio, et biennio uno concludo,
 brevissimo deinceps spatio institutionem totam sive ἀγωγὴν
 absoluturus. Romanos et tot gentes respicio, quae Romanum-
 olim sermonem assumpserunt. Erat lingua, priusquam gram-
 matica esset : difficilis, postquam tormenta ista accesserunt.
 Cum sola consuetudo peritiam gigneret, doctissimi et facun-
 dissimi erant viri; ars accedebat; ornamento, non oneri
 erat. Ut longissima linguae praecepta nata sunt, loqui ditiicile
 fuit. Arte opus fuisse fateor, ut semel extincta latinitas ad
 vitam revocaretur : sed quia viventem jam habemus, cur
 tanquam mortuam quaerimusi Cur, parata via, per anfractus
 discurrimus? Error est, et scholas passim ac gymnasia
 trahit. Periculum me-hercle erat, ne academiae cessarent,
 si tot regulae, tot cruces, tot salebrae grammaticorum dees-
 sent. Ego sic existimo, omnes ejusdem genii linguas esse,
 omnes usu constitui, usu addisci. Auxilia tamen non rejiciam,

 IX. Uni se linguae Latinae omnes mancipent, quotidiani

 X. Sub praefecto duo praeceptores sive paedagogi sint :
 alter morum, atter litterarum, uterque Latinus. IIIe morum
 a curatore, hic litterarum a praefecto constituatur.
